TITLE: Asynchronous SNMP GETBULK Walk Operation with PySNMP in Python
DESCRIPTION: This script demonstrates how to perform an asynchronous SNMP walk operation using the GETBULK command with PySNMP's high-level API. It retrieves SNMP data from a remote agent, continuing until the end of the MIB is reached.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/examples/hlapi/v1arch/asyncio/manager/cmdgen/walking-operations.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
"""  #
Fetch whole SNMP table at once using GETBULK operation.

Send a series of SNMP GETBULK requests using the following options:

* with SNMPv2c, community 'public'
* over IPv4/UDP
* to an Agent at demo.snmplabs.com:161
* for all OIDs within 1.3.6.1.2.1.1 (sysDescr)
* run till end-of-mib condition is reported by Agent
* based on asyncio I/O framework

Asynchronous Python 3.5+ code

This script performs similar to the following Net-SNMP command:

| $ snmpbulkwalk -v2c -c public -Cr50 demo.snmplabs.com 1.3.6.1.2.1.1

"""
```

TITLE: Performing SNMPv2c/v3 GETBULK Operation with PySNMP Asyncio
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to perform an SNMPv2c/v3 GETBULK operation using PySNMP's asyncio-based high-level API. It retrieves multiple OIDs from the IF-MIB::ifTable with specified non-repeaters and max-repetitions.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/examples/hlapi/v3arch/asyncio/manager/cmdgen/snmp-versions.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# GETBULK with limits on variable-bindings and rows
#
# Perform SNMP GETBULK operation using the following options:
#
# * with SNMPv2c
# * with community name 'public'
# * over IPv4/UDP
# * to an Agent at localhost:161
# * for some columns of the IF-MIB::ifTable table
# * with non-repeaters=0 and max-repetitions=25
# * stop when response OIDs leave the scop of the table
#
# This script performs similar to the following Net-SNMP command:
#
# $ snmpbulkget -v2c -c public -Cn0 -Cr25 -ObentU localhost:161 1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.2 1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.3

from pysnmp.hlapi.v3arch.asyncio import *

async def run():
    snmpEngine = SnmpEngine()
    
    await getbulk(
        snmpEngine,
        CommunityData('public'),
        UdpTransportTarget(('localhost', 161)),
        ContextData(),
        0, 25,
        ObjectType(ObjectIdentity('IF-MIB', 'ifTable')),
        lexicographicMode=False,
        lookupMib=True
    )

    snmpEngine.transportDispatcher.closeDispatcher()

if __name__ == '__main__':
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(run())

```

TITLE: Multiple Concurrent SNMP Queries Over IPv4 and IPv6 Using PySNMP and asyncio
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to perform multiple concurrent SNMP GET queries over both IPv4 and IPv6 using PySNMP's high-level API with asyncio. The script queries multiple devices simultaneously and processes their responses asynchronously.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/examples/hlapi/v1arch/asyncio/manager/cmdgen/advanced-topics.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# This script performs concurrent SNMP GET operations using asyncio

import asyncio
from pysnmp.hlapi.v1arch.asyncio import (
    getCmd, SnmpDispatcher, CommunityData, UdpTransportTarget,
    UdpTransportTarget6, ContextData, SnmpEngine, ObjectType,
    ObjectIdentity
)

# List of targets in (transport, community) format
targets = [
    (UdpTransportTarget(('demo.snmplabs.com', 161)), CommunityData('public')),
    (UdpTransportTarget(('demo.snmplabs.com', 1161)), CommunityData('public')),
    (UdpTransportTarget6(('::1', 161)), CommunityData('public'))
]

# Multiple OIDs to query
objectIdentities = [
    ObjectIdentity('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysDescr', 0),
    ObjectIdentity('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysLocation', 0)
]


async def getone(snmpEngine, transport, community):
    errorIndication, errorStatus, errorIndex, varBinds = await getCmd(
        snmpEngine,
        community,
        transport,
        ContextData(),
        *[ObjectType(x) for x in objectIdentities]
    )

    if errorIndication or errorStatus:
        print(transport.getLocalAddress(),
              errorIndication or errorStatus.prettyPrint())
    else:
        for varBind in varBinds:  # SNMP response contents
            print(' = '.join([str(x) for x in varBind]))


async def run():
    # Create and pass a separate SNMP engine for each task
    tasks = []
    for transport, community in targets:
        snmpEngine = SnmpEngine()
        tasks.append(getone(snmpEngine, transport, community))

    # Run all SNMP queries asynchronously
    await asyncio.gather(*tasks)


loop = asyncio.get_event_loop()
loop.run_until_complete(run())
loop.close()
```

TITLE: Configuring SNMP Agent with Multiple USM Users using PySNMP and asyncio in Python
DESCRIPTION: This script sets up an SNMP agent with multiple USM users, each with different authentication and privacy protocols. It uses the PySNMP library and asyncio for asynchronous operation. The agent is configured to listen on UDP port 161 and respond to SNMP GET/GETNEXT/GETBULK queries.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/examples/v3arch/asyncio/agent/cmdrsp/snmp-versions.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# SNMP agent with multiple USM users

from pysnmp.entity import engine, config
from pysnmp.entity.rfc3413 import cmdrsp, context
from pysnmp.carrier.asyncio.dgram import udp
from pysnmp.proto import api
from pysnmp.proto.api import v2c

import asyncio

# Create SNMP engine
snmpEngine = engine.SnmpEngine()

# Transport setup

# UDP over IPv4
config.addTransport(
    snmpEngine,
    udp.domainName,
    udp.UdpTransport().openServerMode(('localhost', 161))
)

# SNMPv3/USM setup

# user: usr-md5-des, auth: MD5, priv DES
config.addV3User(
    snmpEngine,
    'usr-md5-des',
    config.usmHMACMD5AuthProtocol, 'authkey1',
    config.usmDESPrivProtocol, 'privkey1'
)

# user: usr-sha-none, auth: SHA, priv NONE
config.addV3User(
    snmpEngine,
    'usr-sha-none',
    config.usmHMACSHAAuthProtocol, 'authkey1'
)

# user: usr-sha-aes128, auth: SHA, priv AES
config.addV3User(
    snmpEngine,
    'usr-sha-aes128',
    config.usmHMACSHAAuthProtocol, 'authkey1',
    config.usmAesCfb128Protocol, 'privkey1'
)

# Allow full MIB access for each user at VACM
config.addVacmUser(snmpEngine, 3, 'usr-md5-des', 'authPriv', (1, 3, 6, 1, 2, 1), (1, 3, 6, 1, 2, 1))
config.addVacmUser(snmpEngine, 3, 'usr-sha-none', 'authNoPriv', (1, 3, 6, 1, 2, 1), (1, 3, 6, 1, 2, 1))
config.addVacmUser(snmpEngine, 3, 'usr-sha-aes128', 'authPriv', (1, 3, 6, 1, 2, 1), (1, 3, 6, 1, 2, 1))

# Get default SNMP context this SNMP engine serves
snmpContext = context.SnmpContext(snmpEngine)

# Register SNMP Applications at the SNMP engine for particular SNMP context
cmdrsp.GetCommandResponder(snmpEngine, snmpContext)
cmdrsp.NextCommandResponder(snmpEngine, snmpContext)
cmdrsp.BulkCommandResponder(snmpEngine, snmpContext)

# Register an imaginary never-ending job to keep I/O dispatcher running forever
async def run():
    while True:
        await asyncio.sleep(1)

loop = asyncio.get_event_loop()
loop.create_task(run())

# Run I/O dispatcher which would receive queries and send responses
loop.run_forever()
```

TITLE: Listening on IPv4 and IPv6 Interfaces for SNMP Notifications using asyncio and PySNMP
DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to configure a SNMP manager to listen for notifications on both IPv4 and IPv6 interfaces simultaneously using PySNMP's asyncio interface. The example shows how to set up transport dispatchers for both IP protocols and handle incoming SNMP notifications asynchronously.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/examples/v1arch/asyncio/manager/ntfrcv/transport-tweaks.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
#!/usr/bin/env python
#
# Listen and receive SNMP TRAP/INFORM messages over both IPv4 and
# IPv6 transports in asyncio paradigm.
#
# This script can receive both TRAP and INFORM SNMP notifications from
# IPv4 and IPv6 sources at once.
#
# Try to run this script and send TRAP/INFORM using snmptrap or
# snmpinform utilities like this (assuming net-snmp on the other end):
#
# $ snmptrap -v2c -c public 127.0.0.1:162 123 1.3.6.1.6.3.1.1.5.1
# $ snmptrap -v2c -c public udp6:[::1]:162 123 1.3.6.1.6.3.1.1.5.1
# $ snmpinform -v2c -c public 127.0.0.1:162 123 1.3.6.1.6.3.1.1.5.1
# $ snmpinform -v2c -c public udp6:[::1]:162 123 1.3.6.1.6.3.1.1.5.1
#
# As PySNMP is capable of General PDU processing for both TRAP and
# INFORM notifications, TRAP's are responded with TRAP acknowledgement,
# INFORM's with INFORM response PDUs.
#
from pysnmp.carrier.asyncio.dispatch import AsyncioDispatcher
from pysnmp.carrier.asyncio.dgram import udp, udp6
from pysnmp.proto import api
from pysnmp import debug

# debug.setLogger(debug.Debug('all'))

# Create SNMP engine
snmpEngine = api.SnmpEngine()

# Transport setup

# UDP over IPv4, first listening interface/port
config = udp.UdpTransport().openServerMode(('127.0.0.1', 162))
snmpEngine.registerTransport(udp.DOMAIN_NAME, config)

# UDP over IPv6, second listening interface/port
config = udp6.Udp6Transport().openServerMode(('::1', 162))
snmpEngine.registerTransport(udp6.DOMAIN_NAME, config)

# SNMPv1/2c setup

# SecurityName <-> CommunityName mapping
config = api.CommunityData('public', 'public')
snmpEngine.registerCommunityData(config)

# Callback function for receiving notifications


def cbFun(snmpEngine, stateReference, contextEngineId, contextName,
          varBinds, cbCtx):
    print('Notification from ContextEngineId "%s", ContextName "%s"' %
          (contextEngineId.prettyPrint(), contextName.prettyPrint()))
    for name, val in varBinds:
        print('%s = %s' % (name.prettyPrint(), val.prettyPrint()))


# Register SNMP Application at the SNMP engine
cmd = api.CommandResponderData(snmpEngine, cbFun)
snmpEngine.registerCmdResp(cmd)

# Run I/O dispatcher which would receive queries and send responses
asyncoDispatcher = AsyncioDispatcher()
asyncoDispatcher.registerTransport(
    udp.DOMAIN_NAME, udp.UdpAsyncioProtocol())
asyncoDispatcher.registerTransport(
    udp6.DOMAIN_NAME, udp6.Udp6AsyncioProtocol())
asyncoDispatcher.registerRecvCbFun(snmpEngine.receiveMessage)
asyncioLoop = asyncioDispatcher.getEventLoop()

transport = asyncioDispatcher.getTransport(udp.DOMAIN_NAME)
print('Listening at %s' % (transport.getLocalAddress(), ))

transport = asyncioDispatcher.getTransport(udp6.DOMAIN_NAME)
print('Listening at %s' % (transport.getLocalAddress(), ))

asyncioLoop.run_forever()
```

TITLE: Sending SNMP Informs over IPv4 and IPv6 using pysnmp
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet shows how to configure and send SNMP informs over both IPv4 and IPv6 networks using pysnmp. It sets up the SNMP engine, configures transport settings, and sends inform notifications asynchronously.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/examples/v1arch/asyncio/agent/ntforg/transport-tweaks.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# Send SNMP INFORM via IPv4/UDP
config.addTransport(
    snmpEngine,
    udp.domainName,
    udp.UdpTransport().openClientMode()
)

# Send SNMP INFORM via IPv6/UDP
config.addTransport(
    snmpEngine,
    udp6.domainName,
    udp6.Udp6Transport().openClientMode()
)

# Setup transport endpoint addresses
config.addTargetAddr(
    snmpEngine, 'my-nms-1',
    udp.domainName, ('104.236.166.95', 162),
    'my-creds', timeout=6, retryCount=2
)
config.addTargetAddr(
    snmpEngine, 'my-nms-2',
    udp6.domainName, ('::1', '162'),
    'my-creds', timeout=6, retryCount=2
)

# Setup notification targets
config.addNotificationTarget(
    snmpEngine, 'my-notify', 'my-filter', 'my-nms-1', 'my-inform'
)
config.addNotificationTarget(
    snmpEngine, 'my-notify', 'my-filter', 'my-nms-2', 'my-inform'
)

# Specify what kind of notification should be sent (TRAP or INFORM)
config.addContext(snmpEngine, '')
config.addVacmUser(snmpEngine, 2, 'my-user', 'noAuthNoPriv', (), ())

# Create Notification Originator
ntfOrg = ntforg.NotificationOriginator(snmpContext)

# Build and submit notification message to dispatcher
ntfOrg.sendVarBinds(
    snmpEngine,
    'my-notify',  # notification targets
    None, '',  # contextEngineId, contextName
    # var-binds
    [
        ('1.3.6.1.2.1.1.3.0', v2c.TimeTicks(12039208)),
        ('1.3.6.1.6.3.1.1.5.1', v2c.ObjectIdentifier('1.3.6.1.6.3.1.1.5.1')),
        ('1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.1.123', v2c.Integer(123)),
        ('1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.7.123', v2c.Integer(1)),
        ('1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.8.123', v2c.Integer(1))
    ]
)

snmpEngine.transportDispatcher.runDispatcher()
```

TITLE: Configuring MIB Viewer and Resolving PDU VarBinds in PySNMP
DESCRIPTION: This script demonstrates how to configure a MIB viewer and resolve PDU variable bindings using PySNMP. It shows the process of loading MIB files, creating a MIB viewer, and resolving OIDs to human-readable form.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/examples/smi/manager/browsing-mib-tree.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from pysnmp.smi import builder, view, compiler, rfc1902

mibBuilder = builder.MibBuilder()
mibViewController = view.MibViewController(mibBuilder)

compiler.addMibCompiler(mibBuilder, sources=['file:///usr/share/snmp/mibs',
                                              'http://mibs.snmplabs.com/asn1/@mib@'])

mibBuilder.loadModules('SNMPv2-MIB', 'SNMP-COMMUNITY-MIB')

oid = rfc1902.ObjectIdentity('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysDescr', 0)
oid.resolveWithMib(mibViewController)
print(oid.prettyPrint())

proto = rfc1902.Integer(123)
proto.resolveWithMib(mibViewController)
print(proto.prettyPrint())

vb = rfc1902.ObjectType(rfc1902.ObjectIdentity('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysDescr', 0), 'Linux i386')
vb.resolveWithMib(mibViewController)
print(vb.prettyPrint())
```

TITLE: Sending Multiple SNMP Traps at Once with PySNMP and asyncio in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to send multiple SNMP trap notifications concurrently using PySNMP's asyncio-based high-level API. It creates SNMPv3 authenticated trap notifications directed to multiple managers.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/examples/hlapi/v3arch/asyncio/agent/ntforg/advanced-topics.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# Send multiple TRAP notifications at once using asyncio.
#
# Here we send the same TRAP to multiple Managers at once.
# We do this by building a list of coroutines and scheduling
# them for execution via asyncio.gather()

from pysnmp.hlapi.v3arch.asyncio import *

async def run():
    snmpEngine = SnmpEngine()

    # Define list of targets
    targets = [
        (
            UdpTransportTarget(('demo.snmplabs.com', 162)),
            CommunityData('public')
        ),
        (
            Udp6TransportTarget(('::1', 162)),
            CommunityData('public')
        ),
        (
            UdpTransportTarget(('127.0.0.1', 162)),
            UsmUserData('usr-sha-aes128', 'authkey1', 'privkey1',
                        authProtocol=usmHMACSHAAuthProtocol,
                        privProtocol=usmAesCfb128Protocol)
        ),
    ]

    # Send TRAP to all targets

    return await asyncio.gather(
        *[sendNotification(
            snmpEngine,
            authData,
            transportTarget,
            ContextData(),
            'trap',
            # sequence of OIDs-values
            [
                # SNMPv2-MIB::sysUpTime.0 = 123
                (('1.3.6.1.2.1.1.3.0', TimeTicks(123)),),
                # SNMPv2-MIB::snmpTrapOID.0 = SNMPv2-MIB::warmStart
                (('1.3.6.1.6.3.1.1.4.1.0', ObjectIdentifier('1.3.6.1.6.3.1.1.5.2')),),
                # Some payload
                (('1.3.6.1.2.1.1.1.0', OctetString('Hello from asyncio TRAP ')),),
            ]
          ) for transportTarget, authData in targets]
    )

if __name__ == '__main__':
    asyncio.run(run())
```

TITLE: Implementing IP-MIB Table in PySNMP Agent
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to create and register a static IP-MIB table in a PySNMP agent. It imports necessary symbols from IP-MIB, creates MibScalarInstance objects for each table column, and registers them with the SNMP engine. The example creates a single row with the IP address 1.2.3.4 and related attributes.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/faq/how-to-implement-agent-mib.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# SNMP Agent (AKA CommandResponder) is built around SNMP engine object
snmpEngine = engine.SnmpEngine()

# Import table columns
( ipAddressAddrType,
  ipAddressAddr,
  ipAddressIfIndex,
  ipAddressType,
  ipAddressPrefix,
  ipAddressOrigin,
  ipAddressStatus,
  ipAddressCreated,
  ipAddressLastChanged,
  ipAddressRowStatus,
  ipAddressStorageType ) = snmpEngine.get_mib_builder().import_symbols(
  'IP-MIB',
  'ipAddressAddrType',
  'ipAddressAddr',
  'ipAddressIfIndex',
  'ipAddressType',
  'ipAddressPrefix',
  'ipAddressOrigin',
  'ipAddressStatus',
  'ipAddressCreated',
  'ipAddressLastChanged',
  'ipAddressRowStatus',
  'ipAddressStorageType'
)

# Import MibScalarInstance

MibScalarInstance, = snmpEngine.get_mib_builder().import_symbols('SNMPv2-SMI', 'MibScalarInstance')

# Create table columns instances

_ipAddressAddrType = MibScalarInstance(
    ipAddressAddrType.name, (1, 4, 1, 2, 3, 4),
    ipAddressAddrType.syntax.clone(1)
)
_ipAddressAddr = MibScalarInstance(
    ipAddressAddr.name, (1, 4, 1, 2, 3, 4),
    ipAddressAddr.syntax.clone('1.2.3.4')
)
_ipAddressIfIndex = MibScalarInstance(
    ipAddressIfIndex.name, (1, 4, 1, 2, 3, 4),
    ipAddressIfIndex.syntax.clone(1)
)
_ipAddressType = MibScalarInstance(
    ipAddressType.name, (1, 4, 1, 2, 3, 4),
    ipAddressType.syntax.clone(1)
)
_ipAddressPrefix = MibScalarInstance(
    ipAddressPrefix.name, (1, 4, 1, 2, 3, 4),
    ipAddressPrefix.syntax.clone((0,0))
)
_ipAddressOrigin = MibScalarInstance(
    ipAddressOrigin.name, (1, 4, 1, 2, 3, 4),
    ipAddressOrigin.syntax.clone(1)
)
_ipAddressStatus = MibScalarInstance(
    ipAddressStatus.name, (1, 4, 1, 2, 3, 4),
    ipAddressStatus.syntax.clone(1)
)
_ipAddressCreated = MibScalarInstance(
    ipAddressCreated.name, (1, 4, 1, 2, 3, 4),
    ipAddressCreated.syntax.clone(800)
)
_ipAddressLastChanged = MibScalarInstance(
    ipAddressLastChanged.name, (1, 4, 1, 2, 3, 4),
    ipAddressLastChanged.syntax.clone(600)
)
_ipAddressRowStatus = MibScalarInstance(
    ipAddressRowStatus.name, (1, 4, 1, 2, 3, 4),
    ipAddressRowStatus.syntax.clone(1)
)
_ipAddressStorageType = MibScalarInstance(
    ipAddressStorageType.name, (1, 4, 1, 2, 3, 4),
    ipAddressStorageType.syntax
)

# add anonymous column instances
snmpEngine.get_mib_builder().export_symbols(
    '_IP-MIB',
    _ipAddressAddrType,
    _ipAddressAddr,
    _ipAddressIfIndex,
    _ipAddressType,
    _ipAddressPrefix,
    _ipAddressOrigin,
    _ipAddressStatus,
    _ipAddressCreated,
    _ipAddressLastChanged,
    _ipAddressRowStatus,
    _ipAddressStorageType
    )

# Command responder code would follow...
```

TITLE: Implementing Scalar MIB Objects over IPv4 and IPv6 with PySNMP in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to implement scalar MIB objects for SNMP agents using PySNMP's v1arch and asyncio modules. It sets up SNMP engine, transport dispatchers, and community-based security model for both IPv4 and IPv6. The script defines MIB scalar objects and their values, then starts the SNMP engine to serve GET/GETNEXT requests.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/examples/v1arch/asyncio/agent/cmdrsp/agent-side-mib-implementations.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# Implement scalar MIB objects at unified SNMPv2-MIB with SNMPv1/SNMPv2c
#     agent using asyncio

# Send SNMPv1/v2c GET/GETNEXT requests to localhost:161
# with community name 'public'

# This script can respond to both IPv4 and IPv6 queries

from pysnmp.entity import engine, config
from pysnmp.entity.rfc3413 import cmdrsp, context
from pysnmp.carrier.asyncio.dgram import udp, udp6
from pysnmp.proto.api import v2c
import asyncio

# Create SNMP engine
snmpEngine = engine.SnmpEngine()

# Transport setup

# UDP over IPv4
config.addTransport(
    snmpEngine,
    udp.domainName,
    udp.UdpTransport().openServerMode(('127.0.0.1', 161))
)

# UDP over IPv6
config.addTransport(
    snmpEngine,
    udp6.domainName,
    udp6.Udp6Transport().openServerMode(('::1', 161))
)

# SNMPv1/2c setup

# SecurityName <-> CommunityName mapping
config.addV1System(snmpEngine, 'my-area', 'public')

# Allow full MIB access for each user at VACM
config.addVacmUser(snmpEngine, 2, 'my-area', 'noAuthNoPriv', (1, 3, 6, 1, 2, 1))
config.addVacmUser(snmpEngine, 1, 'my-area', 'noAuthNoPriv', (1, 3, 6, 1, 2, 1))

# Get default SNMP context this SNMP engine serves
snmpContext = context.SnmpContext(snmpEngine)

# Create an instance of MIB builder
mibBuilder = snmpContext.getMibInstrum().getMibBuilder()

# MIB scalar objects implementation
sysDescr, = mibBuilder.importSymbols('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysDescr')
sysObjectID, = mibBuilder.importSymbols('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysObjectID')
sysUpTime, = mibBuilder.importSymbols('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysUpTime')
sysContact, = mibBuilder.importSymbols('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysContact')
sysName, = mibBuilder.importSymbols('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysName')
sysLocation, = mibBuilder.importSymbols('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysLocation')
sysServices, = mibBuilder.importSymbols('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysServices')
sysORLastChange, = mibBuilder.importSymbols('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysORLastChange')

mibInstrumController = snmpContext.getMibInstrum()
mibInstrumController.writeVars(
    ((sysDescr.name, (v2c.OctetString('PySNMP example agent'))),
     (sysObjectID.name, (v2c.ObjectIdentifier((1, 3, 6, 1, 4, 1, 20408)))),
     (sysUpTime.name, (v2c.TimeTicks(0))),
     (sysContact.name, (v2c.OctetString('info@snmplabs.com'))),
     (sysName.name, (v2c.OctetString('example-agent'))),
     (sysLocation.name, (v2c.OctetString('San Francisco, CA, USA'))),
     (sysServices.name, (v2c.Integer32(72))),
     (sysORLastChange.name, (v2c.TimeTicks(0))))
)

# Register SNMP Applications at the SNMP engine for particular SNMP context
cmdrsp.GetCommandResponder(snmpEngine, snmpContext)
cmdrsp.NextCommandResponder(snmpEngine, snmpContext)

asyncio.get_event_loop().run_forever()

DESCRIPTION: Example demonstrating how to perform multiple concurrent SNMP queries over both IPv4 and IPv6 using PySNMP's asyncio framework. This showcases the ability to query multiple SNMP agents simultaneously with different transport protocols.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/examples/hlapi/v3arch/asyncio/manager/cmdgen/advanced-topics.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_2

#
# This example sends a set of SNMP GET requests using asyncio coroutines
# and processes responses as they come in, one at a time.
#
# This script performs concurrent queries to SNMP agents over IPv4 and IPv6
# transports.
#
import asyncio
from pysnmp.hlapi.v3arch.asyncio import *

async def getone(snmpEngine, hostname, community):
    errorIndication, errorStatus, errorIndex, varBinds = await getCmd(
        snmpEngine,
        CommunityData(community),
        UdpTransportTarget((hostname, 161)),
        ContextData(),
        ObjectType(ObjectIdentity('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysDescr', 0))
    )

    if errorIndication or errorStatus:
        print(hostname, errorIndication or errorStatus)
    else:
        for varBind in varBinds:
            print(' = '.join([x.prettyPrint() for x in varBind]))

async def getv6one(snmpEngine, hostname, community):
    errorIndication, errorStatus, errorIndex, varBinds = await getCmd(
        snmpEngine,
        CommunityData(community),
        Udp6TransportTarget((hostname, 161)),
        ContextData(),
        ObjectType(ObjectIdentity('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysDescr', 0))
    )

    if errorIndication or errorStatus:
        print(hostname, errorIndication or errorStatus)
    else:
        for varBind in varBinds:
            print(' = '.join([x.prettyPrint() for x in varBind]))


snmpEngine = SnmpEngine()

loop = asyncio.get_event_loop()

loop.run_until_complete(
    asyncio.gather(
        getone(snmpEngine, 'demo.snmplabs.com', 'public'),
        getv6one(snmpEngine, 'localhost', 'public')
    )
)

loop.close()
```

from pysnmp.smi import builder, view, compiler, error

TITLE: Walking MIB using GETBULK operation with asyncio in PySNMP
DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to walk through an entire MIB tree using SNMP GETBULK operation with PySNMP's asyncio architecture. GETBULK retrieves multiple MIB objects in a single request, offering better performance compared to GETNEXT for large MIBs.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/examples/v1arch/asyncio/manager/cmdgen/walking-operations.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# This script performs SNMP GETBULK operations on the specified Agent.
# It uses PySNMP's asyncio-based v1arch API.

from pysnmp.v1arch.asyncio.cmdgen import getCmd, bulkCmd
from pysnmp.v1arch.proto import rfc1902
from pysnmp.error import PySnmpError
import asyncio

# List of targets in form target[(auth), (transport)]
targets = [
    # 1-st target (SNMPv2c over IPv4/UDP)
    (('public', 'snmpv2c'),
     ('demo.snmplabs.com', 162)),
]

async def getbulk(hostname, port, community, objectId):
    # Create SNMP request generator
    snmpEngine = bulkCmd(
        # Security parameters
        (community, 'snmpv2c'),
        # Transport parameters
        (hostname, port),
        # GETBULK options
        0, 25,
        # MIB this request is about
        objectId
    )

    varBindTable = None

    while True:
        try:
            # Submit async request
            varBindTable = await snmpEngine.send(varBindTable)

            for varBindRow in varBindTable:
                for varName, varVal in varBindRow:
                    print(f'{varName.prettyPrint()} = {varVal.prettyPrint()}')

        except PySnmpError as e:
            print(f'SNMP request failed: {e}')
            break

        except KeyboardInterrupt:
            print('Shutdown requested...')
            break

        except Exception as e:
            print(f'Unexpected exception: {e}')
            break

async def main():
    # Run all command generators
    for authData, transportTarget in targets:
        await getbulk(
            transportTarget[0], transportTarget[1],
            authData[0],
            '1.3.6'
        )

if __name__ == '__main__':
    asyncio.run(main())
```

TITLE: Walking SNMP Tables with AsyncIO GETBULK Operation in Python
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to perform SNMP GETBULK operations using PySNMP's AsyncIO API to efficiently walk through SNMP tables until reaching the end of MIB. This implementation handles authentication, performs the GETBULK requests asynchronously, and collects the response data.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/examples/hlapi/v3arch/asyncio/manager/cmdgen/walking-operations.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# GETBULK command generator
#
# Perform SNMP GETBULK operation using the following options:
#
# * with SNMPv3 with user 'usr-md5-des', MD5 auth and DES privacy
# * over IPv4/UDP
# * to an Agent at 104.236.166.95:161
# * for OIDs in tuple form
# * stop when response OIDs leave the scopes of initial OIDs
# * run inside asyncio loop

from pysnmp.hlapi.v3arch.asyncio import *


async def run():
    # AsyncCommandGenerator handles SNMP engine and network transport
    async with AsyncCommandGenerator(
            # SecurityParameters provides configuration for authentication
            SecurityParameters(
                securityModel=3,
                securityName='usr-md5-des',
                securityLevel='auth-priv',
                authKey='authkey1',
                authProtocol='md5',
                privKey='privkey1',
                privProtocol='des'
            ),
            # UDP over IPv4
            UdpTransportTarget(('104.236.166.95', 161))
    ) as snmp_engine:

        count = 0
        object_types = (
            ObjectType(ObjectIdentity('1.3.6'))
        )
        initial_object_types = object_types

        # Loop through GETBULK requests until response OIDs
        # leave the scope of the initial OIDs
        while 1:
            result = await snmp_engine.getbulk(
                ContextData(),
                non_repeaters=0, max_repetitions=50,
                *object_types
            )

            error_indication, error_status, error_index, var_binds = result

            if error_indication:
                print(error_indication)
                break
            elif error_status:
                print('%s at %s' % (
                    error_status.prettyPrint(),
                    error_index and var_binds[int(error_index) - 1][0] or '?'
                ))
                break
            else:
                for var_bind in var_binds:
                    object_type, object_value = var_bind

                    # Check if response OIDs are within initial OIDs scope
                    for initial_object_type in initial_object_types:
                        if object_type.isPrefixOf(initial_object_type[0]):
                            break
                    else:
                        return

                    count += 1

                    print('%s = %s' % (object_type.prettyPrint(),
                                       object_value.prettyPrint()))

                # Check if we reached end of MIB
                if var_binds[-1][1].isEndOfMib():
                    return

                # Update request with the last OID retrieved from response
                object_types = var_binds[-1:]

        print('Total objects retrieved: %s' % count)


if __name__ == '__main__':
    import asyncio

    asyncio.run(run())
```

DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to perform multiple sequential SNMP GET queries using PySNMP's high-level API with asyncio. The script queries each device one after another in a sequential manner and processes their responses.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/examples/hlapi/v1arch/asyncio/manager/cmdgen/advanced-topics.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# This script performs sequential SNMP GET operations using asyncio

import asyncio
from pysnmp.hlapi.v1arch.asyncio import (
    getCmd, CommunityData, UdpTransportTarget, ContextData,
    SnmpEngine, ObjectType, ObjectIdentity
)

# List of targets in (transport, community) format
targets = [
    (UdpTransportTarget(('demo.snmplabs.com', 161)), CommunityData('public')),
    (UdpTransportTarget(('demo.snmplabs.com', 1161)), CommunityData('public'))
]

# Multiple OIDs to query
objectIdentities = [
    ObjectIdentity('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysDescr', 0),
    ObjectIdentity('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysObjectID', 0)
]


async def run():
    # Create shared SNMP engine
    snmpEngine = SnmpEngine()

    # Submit GET requests one by one
    for transport, community in targets:
        errorIndication, errorStatus, errorIndex, varBinds = await getCmd(
            snmpEngine,
            community,
            transport,
            ContextData(),
            *[ObjectType(x) for x in objectIdentities]
        )

        if errorIndication or errorStatus:
            print(transport.getLocalAddress(),
                  errorIndication or errorStatus.prettyPrint())
        else:
            for varBind in varBinds:  # SNMP response contents
                print(' = '.join([str(x) for x in varBind]))


loop = asyncio.get_event_loop()
loop.run_until_complete(run())
loop.close()
```

```
# This script performs a linear SNMP GETNEXT operations on the specified Agent.
# It uses PySNMP's asyncio-based v1arch API.

from pysnmp.v1arch.asyncio.cmdgen import getCmd, nextCmd
from pysnmp.v1arch.proto import rfc1902
from pysnmp.error import PySnmpError
import asyncio

# List of targets in form target[(auth), (transport)]
targets = [
    # 1-st target (SNMPv1 over IPv4/UDP)
    (('public', 'snmpv1'),
     ('demo.snmplabs.com', 162)),
]

async def getbulk(hostname, port, community, objectId):
    # Create SNMP request generator
    snmpEngine = nextCmd(
        # Security parameters
        (community, 'snmpv1'),
        # Transport parameters
        (hostname, port),
        # MIB this request is about
        objectId
    )

    varBinds = None

    while True:
        try:
            # Submit async request
            varBinds = await snmpEngine.send(varBinds)

            for varName, varVal in varBinds:
                print(f'{varName.prettyPrint()} = {varVal.prettyPrint()}')

        except PySnmpError as e:
            print(f'SNMP request failed: {e}')
            break

        except KeyboardInterrupt:
            print('Shutdown requested...')
            break

        except Exception as e:
            print(f'Unexpected exception: {e}')
            break

async def main():
    # Run all command generators
    for authData, transportTarget in targets:
        await getbulk(
            transportTarget[0], transportTarget[1],
            authData[0],
            '1.3.6'
        )

if __name__ == '__main__':
    asyncio.run(main())
```

    else:
        for oid, val in varBinds:
            print('%s = %s' % (oid.prettyPrint(), val.prettyPrint()))

# (OID sub-tree) to callback function


async def getScalar(oid):
    loop = asyncio.get_event_loop()
    return await loop.create_future()


async def run():

    oid = (1, 3, 6, 1, 2, 1, 1, 1, 0)

DESCRIPTION: Example demonstrating how to perform multiple sequential SNMP queries using PySNMP's asyncio framework. This showcases the ability to query multiple SNMP agents in sequence, waiting for each response before proceeding to the next query.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/examples/hlapi/v3arch/asyncio/manager/cmdgen/advanced-topics.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_3

CODE:
```
#
# This example sends a bunch of SNMP GET requests in a serialized manner
# using asyncio. It sends a request, wait till response arrives and sends
# another request and so on.
#
import asyncio
from pysnmp.hlapi.v3arch.asyncio import *

# List of targets in the followin format:
# ( (authData, transportTarget, varNames), ... )
#
targets = (
    # 1-st target (SNMPv1 over IPv4/UDP)
    (CommunityData('public', mpModel=0),
     UdpTransportTarget(('demo.snmplabs.com', 161)),
     (ObjectType(ObjectIdentity('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysDescr', 0)),
      ObjectType(ObjectIdentity('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysName', 0)))),
    # 2-nd target (SNMPv2c over IPv4/UDP)
    (CommunityData('public'),
     UdpTransportTarget(('demo.snmplabs.com', 161)),
     (ObjectType(ObjectIdentity('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysUpTime', 0)),
      ObjectType(ObjectIdentity('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysORLastChange', 0))))
)

async def getone(snmpEngine, authData, transportTarget, varBinds):
    errorIndication, errorStatus, errorIndex, varBinds = await getCmd(
        snmpEngine,
        authData,
        transportTarget,
        ContextData(),
        *varBinds
    )

    if errorIndication or errorStatus:
        print(transportTarget.transportAddr,
              errorIndication or errorStatus.prettyPrint())
    else:
        for varBind in varBinds:
            print(' = '.join([x.prettyPrint() for x in varBind]))


snmpEngine = SnmpEngine()

loop = asyncio.get_event_loop()

tasks = [
    getone(snmpEngine, *target)
    for target in targets
]

loop.run_until_complete(asyncio.gather(*tasks))

loop.close()
```

TITLE: Sending Multiple SNMP Informs at Once with PySNMP and asyncio in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to send multiple SNMP inform notifications concurrently using PySNMP's asyncio-based high-level API. It creates SNMPv3 authenticated inform notifications directed to multiple managers.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/examples/hlapi/v3arch/asyncio/agent/ntforg/advanced-topics.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# Send multiple INFORM notifications at once using asyncio.
#
# Here we send the same INFORM to multiple Managers at once.
# We do this by building a list of coroutines and scheduling
# them for execution via asyncio.gather()

from pysnmp.hlapi.v3arch.asyncio import *

async def run():
    snmpEngine = SnmpEngine()

    # Define list of targets
    targets = [
        (
            UdpTransportTarget(('demo.snmplabs.com', 162)),
            CommunityData('public')
        ),
        (
            Udp6TransportTarget(('::1', 162)),
            CommunityData('public')
        ),
        (
            UdpTransportTarget(('127.0.0.1', 162)),
            UsmUserData('usr-sha-aes128', 'authkey1', 'privkey1',
                        authProtocol=usmHMACSHAAuthProtocol,
                        privProtocol=usmAesCfb128Protocol)
        ),
    ]

    # Send INFORM to all targets
    # noinspection PyTypeChecker
    return await asyncio.gather(
        *[sendNotification(
            snmpEngine,
            authData,
            transportTarget,
            ContextData(),
            'inform',
            # sequence of OIDs-values
            [
                # SNMPv2-MIB::sysUpTime.0 = 123
                (('1.3.6.1.2.1.1.3.0', TimeTicks(123)),),
                # SNMPv2-MIB::snmpTrapOID.0 = SNMPv2-MIB::warmStart
                (('1.3.6.1.6.3.1.1.4.1.0', ObjectIdentifier('1.3.6.1.6.3.1.1.5.2')),),
                # Some payload
                (('1.3.6.1.2.1.1.1.0', OctetString('Hello from asyncio INFORM')),),
            ]
          ) for transportTarget, authData in targets], 
          return_exceptions=True
    )

if __name__ == '__main__':
    asyncio.run(run())
```

--
-- Top-level infrastructure of the PySNMP project enterprise MIB tree
--

IMPORTS
    MODULE-IDENTITY, enterprises FROM SNMPv2-SMI;

pysnmp MODULE-IDENTITY
    LAST-UPDATED "201704140000Z"
    ORGANIZATION "The PySNMP Project"
    CONTACT-INFO "E-mail: LeXtudio Inc. <support@lextudio.com>
                  GitHub: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp"

    DESCRIPTION  "Updated addresses"
    REVISION     "200505140000Z"
    DESCRIPTION  "Initial revision"
    ::= { enterprises 20408 }


--

--

pysnmpObjects              OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= {pysnmp 1}
pysnmpExamples             OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= {pysnmp 2}
pysnmpEnumerations         OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= {pysnmp 3}
pysnmpModuleIDs            OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= {pysnmpEnumerations 1}
pysnmpAgentOIDs            OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= {pysnmpEnumerations 2}
pysnmpDomains              OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= {pysnmpEnumerations 3}
pysnmpExperimental         OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= {pysnmp 9999}

--
--  Notifications
--

pysnmpNotificationPrefix   OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= {pysnmp 4}
pysnmpNotifications        OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= {pysnmpNotificationPrefix 0}
pysnmpNotificationObjects  OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= {pysnmpNotificationPrefix 1}

--
--  Conformance
--

pysnmpConformance          OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= {pysnmp 5}
pysnmpCompliances          OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= {pysnmpConformance 1}

END

SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/examples/hlapi/v1arch/asyncio/index.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from pysnmp.hlapi.asyncio import *

async def run():
    snmpEngine = SnmpEngine()
    errorIndication, errorStatus, errorIndex, varBinds = await
        sendNotificationObject(snmpEngine,
                             CommunityData('public', mpModel=0),
                             UdpTransportTarget(('demo.snmplabs.com', 162)),
                             ContextData(),
                             'trap',
                             NotificationType(ObjectIdentity('1.3.6.1.6.3.1.1.5.2')))

    if errorIndication:
        print(errorIndication)
    elif errorStatus:
        print('%s at %s' % (errorStatus.prettyPrint(),
                            errorIndex and varBinds[int(errorIndex)-1][0] or '?'))
    else:
        print('Notification sent')
```

TITLE: Performing SNMPv1 GET Operation with PySNMP Asyncio
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to perform an SNMPv1 GET operation using PySNMP's asyncio-based high-level API. It retrieves a specific OID value from an SNMP agent.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/examples/hlapi/v3arch/asyncio/manager/cmdgen/snmp-versions.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# GETBULK with limits on variable-bindings and rows
#
# Perform SNMP GETBULK operation using the following options:
#
# * with SNMPv2c
# * with community name 'public'
# * over IPv4/UDP
# * to an Agent at localhost:161
# * for some columns of the IF-MIB::ifTable table
# * with non-repeaters=0 and max-repetitions=25
# * stop when response OIDs leave the scop of the table
#
# This script performs similar to the following Net-SNMP command:
#
# $ snmpbulkget -v2c -c public -Cn0 -Cr25 -ObentU localhost:161 1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.2 1.3.6.1.2.1.2.2.1.3

from pysnmp.hlapi.v3arch.asyncio import *

async def run():
    snmpEngine = SnmpEngine()
    
    await getbulk(
        snmpEngine,
        CommunityData('public'),
        UdpTransportTarget(('localhost', 161)),
        ContextData(),
        0, 25,
        ObjectType(ObjectIdentity('IF-MIB', 'ifTable')),
        lexicographicMode=False,
        lookupMib=True
    )

    snmpEngine.transportDispatcher.closeDispatcher()

if __name__ == '__main__':
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(run())

```

    MAX-ACCESS   not-accessible
    STATUS       current
    DESCRIPTION

    ::= { pysnmpUsmSecretEntry 3 }

pysnmpUsmSecretStatus OBJECT-TYPE
    SYNTAX       RowStatus
    MAX-ACCESS   read-create
    STATUS       current
    DESCRIPTION
        "Table status"
    ::= { pysnmpUsmSecretEntry 4 }

TITLE: Modifying SNMP Variables with PySNMP v2c SET Operation
DESCRIPTION: Example script showing how to perform SNMP SET operations using SNMPv2c protocol with PySNMP library in asyncio mode. Demonstrates variable modification on an SNMP agent.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/examples/v1arch/asyncio/manager/cmdgen/modifying-variables.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
#
# SET Command Generator
#
# Send a SNMP SET request
#     with the following object:
#     sysContact.0 = 'info@snmplabs.com'
#
# This script performs similar to the following Net-SNMP command:
#
# $ snmpset -v2c -c private demo.snmplabs.com sysContact.0 s "info@snmplabs.com"
#
from pysnmp.hlapi.v1arch.asyncio import *

async def run():
    snmpEngine = SnmpEngine()

    errorIndication, errorStatus, errorIndex, varBinds = await setCmd(
        snmpEngine,
        CommunityData('private', mpModel=1),
        UdpTransportTarget(('demo.snmplabs.com', 161)),
        ContextData(),
        ObjectType(ObjectIdentity('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysContact', 0),
                  'info@snmplabs.com')
    )

    if errorIndication:
        print(errorIndication)
    elif errorStatus:
        print('%s at %s' % (
            errorStatus.prettyPrint(),
            errorIndex and varBinds[int(errorIndex) - 1][0] or '?'
        ))
    else:
        for varBind in varBinds:
            print(' = '.join([x.prettyPrint() for x in varBind]))

    snmpEngine.transportDispatcher.closeDispatcher()

if __name__ == '__main__':
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(run())
```

TITLE: Sending Default SNMP v1 Trap using PySNMP with AsyncIO
DESCRIPTION: This code demonstrates how to generate and send a standard SNMP v1 trap using PySNMP's high-level API with asyncio. It shows the asynchronous notification originator that connects to an SNMP manager, constructs and sends a trap message.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/examples/hlapi/v3arch/asyncio/agent/ntforg/common-notifications.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# Trigger standard SNMP TRAP via SNMP v1, to a Manager
#
# SNMPv1 TRAP message protocol:
# * SNMPv1TrapPDU
#   * generic-trap: coldStart (0)
#   * specific-trap: 0
#
# TRAP includes the following variable-bindings:
# * sysUpTime.0 = 123
# * snmpTrapOID.0 = 1.3.6.1.6.3.1.1.5.1

from pysnmp.hlapi.v3arch.asyncio import *

# v1/2c specific
from pysnmp.proto import rfc1902
from pysnmp.proto.api import v2c

import asyncio


async def run():
    # Send TRAP v1 notification
    snmpEngine = SnmpEngine()

    errorIndication, errorStatus, errorIndex, varBinds = (
        await sendNotification(
            snmpEngine,
            CommunityData('public'),
            UdpTransportTarget(('localhost', 162)),
            ContextData(),
            'trap',
            NotificationType(
                ObjectIdentity('1.3.6.1.6.3.1.1.5.1')
            ).addVarBinds(
                # sysUpTime is mandatory for TRAP
                ('1.3.6.1.2.1.1.3.0', v2c.Integer32(123))
            )
        )
    )

    if errorIndication:
        print(errorIndication)
    elif errorStatus:
        print('%s at %s' % (
            errorStatus.prettyPrint(),
            errorIndex and varBinds[int(errorIndex) - 1][0] or '?'
        ))
    else:
        for varBind in varBinds:
            print(' = '.join([x.prettyPrint() for x in varBind]))

    # v1 trap setup
    ntforg = NotificationOriginator(snmpEngine)

    errorIndication = await ntforg.sendVarBinds(
        CommunityData('public'),
        UdpTransportTarget(('localhost', 162)),
        ContextData(),
        'trap',
        # SNMPv1 uses PDU-specific approach to identify trap type
        # Generic trap #0 is coldStart
        # Specific trap 0
        # Uptime 123
        # Enterprise OID 1.3.6.1.4.1.20408.4.1.1.2
        v2c.apiTrapPDU.setDefaults(
            v2c.TrapPDU(),
            enterprise='1.3.6.1.4.1.20408.4.1.1.2',
            generic=0,
            specific=0,
            timeStamp=123
        ).getVarBinds()
    )

    if errorIndication:
        print(errorIndication)

    snmpEngine.transportDispatcher.closeDispatcher()


asyncio.run(run())
```

TITLE: Configuring py2exe to include PySNMP MIB modules in setup.py
DESCRIPTION: This setup.py script demonstrates how to properly configure py2exe to include the necessary PySNMP MIB modules. It explicitly lists 'pysnmp.smi.mibs.*' and 'pysnmp.smi.mibs.instances.*' in the 'includes' option, ensuring these modules are packaged with the application.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/faq/py2exe-throws-error.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from distutils.core import setup
import sys

options = {}

if "py2exe" in sys.argv:
  import py2exe
  # fix executables
  options['console'] = ['myapp.py']
  # add files not found my modulefinder
  options['options'] = {
    'py2exe': {
      'includes': [
        'pysnmp.smi.mibs.*',
        'pysnmp.smi.mibs.instances.*'
      ]
    }
  }

setup(**options)
```

TITLE: Defining USM Secret Table for Passphrase Management
DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines a table structure for storing USM user passphrases used for key localization. The table is designed to be consulted during SNMP engine-ID autodiscovery and includes user credentials with authentication and privacy keys.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/mibs/PYSNMP-USM-MIB.txt#2025-04-22_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: ASN.1
CODE:
```
--
-- The pysnmpUsmSecretTable contains a database of USM users passphrases
-- used for key localization. This table may be consulted during SNMP engine-ID
-- autodiscovery procedure.
--

pysnmpUsmSecretTable OBJECT-TYPE
    SYNTAX       SEQUENCE OF PysnmpUsmSecretEntry
    MAX-ACCESS   not-accessible
    STATUS       current
    DESCRIPTION
        "The table of USM users passphrases configured in the SNMP
         engine's Local Configuration Datastore (LCD)."
    ::= { pysnmpUsmMIBObjects 2 }

pysnmpUsmSecretEntry OBJECT-TYPE
    SYNTAX       PysnmpUsmSecretEntry
    MAX-ACCESS   not-accessible
    STATUS       current
    DESCRIPTION
        "Information about a particular USM user credentials."
    INDEX       { IMPLIED pysnmpUsmSecretUserName }
    ::= { pysnmpUsmSecretTable 1 }

PysnmpUsmSecretEntry ::= SEQUENCE {
    pysnmpUsmSecretUserName       SnmpAdminString,
    pysnmpUsmSecretAuthKey        OCTET STRING,
    pysnmpUsmSecretPrivKey        OCTET STRING,
    pysnmpUsmSecretStatus         RowStatus
}
```

TITLE: Using USM Master Keys with PySNMP Asyncio
DESCRIPTION: Example demonstrating how to use USM master keys for SNMP v3 authentication in an asyncio-based PySNMP command generator. This shows how to configure SNMP USM with master authentication and privacy keys.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/examples/hlapi/v3arch/asyncio/manager/cmdgen/advanced-topics.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
#
# This example demonstrates how to use master USM key with asyncio.
#
# SNMPv3 authentication key localization is defined in RFC3414
# Under normal circumstances, human suppliers of USM values deal just
# with master keys and let SNMP engine to derive localized ones.
#
# Here we assume the following values:
#
# USM user: usr-md5-des, auth: MD5, priv: DES
# Auth key: authkey1, priv key: privkey1
#
import asyncio
from pysnmp.hlapi.v3arch.asyncio import *

# use master key
loop = asyncio.get_event_loop()

snmpEngine = SnmpEngine()

# USM supports two-way auth keys localization (auth and privacy keys can be
# localized to specific authoritative SNMP Engine ID). Since we do not know
# specific authoritative SNMP Engine ID till later and do not want to manage
# many localized keys, we will use USM feature to auto-localize master key.

lcd = snmpEngine.msgAndPduDsp.mibInstrumController.mibBuilder.loadModules(
    'SNMP-USER-BASED-SM-MIB'
)

usmUser = lcd['SNMP-USER-BASED-SM-MIB']['usmUserEntry']

# Create a new user in the USM MIB with security name "usr-md5-des" and
# localizaion keys.

result = usmUser.getNode(
    usmUser.name + (3,)  # usmUserAuthProtocol
).syntax.clone(
    usmUser.getNode(usmUser.name + (3,)).syntax.namedValues.getValue(
        'usmHMACMD5AuthProtocol'
    )
)

result = usmUser.getNode(
    usmUser.name + (4,)  # usmUserAuthKeyChange
).syntax.clone(
    'authkey1'
)

result = usmUser.getNode(
    usmUser.name + (5,)  # usmUserPrivProtocol
).syntax.clone(
    usmUser.getNode(usmUser.name + (5,)).syntax.namedValues.getValue(
        'usmDESPrivProtocol'
    )
)

result = usmUser.getNode(
    usmUser.name + (6,)  # usmUserPrivKeyChange
).syntax.clone(
    'privkey1'
)

usmUserEntry, = lcd['SNMP-USER-BASED-SM-MIB']['usmUserTable'].getInstances()

usmUserEntry.registerUser(
    snmpEngine=snmpEngine,
    userName='usr-md5-des',
    securityName='usr-md5-des'
)

# and then we can query whatever SNMP Engine
result = loop.run_until_complete(
    getCmd(
        snmpEngine,
        UsmUserData('usr-md5-des'),
        UdpTransportTarget(('demo.snmplabs.com', 161)),
        ContextData(),
        ObjectType(ObjectIdentity('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysDescr', 0))
    )
)

print(result)
```

TITLE: Defining USM Key Type Configuration
DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines a configuration object for key type specification when configuring USM users. It allows specifying whether keys are plain-text passphrases, pre-hashed passphrases, or localized keys mixed with the SNMP Security Engine ID.

pysnmpUsmKeyType OBJECT-TYPE
    SYNTAX       INTEGER { passphrase (0), master(1), localized(2) }
    MAX-ACCESS   not-accessible
    STATUS       current
    DESCRIPTION "When configuring USM user, the value of this enumeration
                 determines how the keys should be treated. The default
                 value "passphrase" means that given keys are plain-text
                 pass-phrases, "master" indicates that the keys are pre-hashed
                 pass-phrases, while "localized" stands for pre-hashed
                 pass-phrases mixed with SNMP Security Engine ID value."
    DEFVAL      { passphrase }
    ::= { pysnmpUsmCfg 3 }

pysnmpUsmUser       OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= { pysnmpUsmMIBObjects 3 }

TITLE: Using USM Localized Keys with PySNMP Asyncio
DESCRIPTION: Example demonstrating how to use pre-localized USM keys for SNMP v3 authentication in an asyncio-based PySNMP command generator. This shows how to configure SNMP USM with localized authentication and privacy keys for a specific authoritative engine ID.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/examples/hlapi/v3arch/asyncio/manager/cmdgen/advanced-topics.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
#
# This example demonstrates how to use pre-localized USM keys with asyncio.
#
# SNMPv3 authentication key localization is defined in RFC3414
# Localized keys can be used for pre-computing of final keys on a per-user,
# per-SNMP Engine ID basis.
#
# Here we use pre-localized keys to let local SNMP engine communicate
# with a specific remote SNMP engine.
#
# Here we assume the following values:
#
# Local SNMP Engine ID = 0x0102030405
# Remote SNMP Engine ID = 0x0102030405
# Auth key = 0x9c8c650fea1c9cb0ebc9630ac7678f8f
# Priv key = 0x9c8c650fea1c9cb0ebc9630ac7678f8f
#
import asyncio
from pysnmp.hlapi.v3arch.asyncio import *
from pysnmp.proto import rfc1902

loop = asyncio.get_event_loop()

snmpEngine = SnmpEngine(OctetString(hexValue='0102030405'))

# User entry comes from LCD (LocalConfigurationDataBase) which is a
# MIB managed by SNMP Engine.
lcd = snmpEngine.msgAndPduDsp.mibInstrumController.mibBuilder.loadModules(
    'SNMP-USER-BASED-SM-MIB'
)

# Create a new user in the USM MIB with security name "usr-md5-des" and
# localized auth/priv keys.

result = lcd['SNMP-USER-BASED-SM-MIB']['usmUserTable'].adduser(
    snmpEngine,
    rfc1902.OctetString(hexValue='0102030405'),  # SnmpEngineId
    'usr-md5-des',  # userName
    'MD5',  # authentication
    rfc1902.OctetString(hexValue='9c8c650fea1c9cb0ebc9630ac7678f8f'),  # auth key
    'DES',  # privacy
    rfc1902.OctetString(hexValue='9c8c650fea1c9cb0ebc9630ac7678f8f'),  # priv key
    # we are creating a direct entry, so securityName == username
    securityName='usr-md5-des'
)

result = loop.run_until_complete(
    getCmd(
        snmpEngine,
        UsmUserData('usr-md5-des'),
        UdpTransportTarget(('demo.snmplabs.com', 161)),
        ContextData(),
        ObjectType(ObjectIdentity('SNMPv2-MIB', 'sysDescr', 0))
    )
)

print(result)
```

TITLE: Broadcasting SNMP Requests for Agent Discovery in PySNMP with asyncio
DESCRIPTION: This example demonstrates how to use broadcast techniques to discover SNMP agents on a network. The script sends broadcast SNMP requests and processes responses from any agents on the network. It uses asyncio for asynchronous network operations.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/examples/v1arch/asyncio/manager/cmdgen/transport-tweaks.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# Send broadcast SNMP GET request
#
# The following script sends a SNMP GET request to broadcast address which
# will be responded by any SNMP agent (within the same broadcast domain or
# behind UDP packet forwarder).
#
# This script performs similar to the following Net-SNMP command:
#
# $ snmpget -v1 -c public 255.255.255.255 1.3.6.1.2.1.1.1.0

from pysnmp.carrier.asyncio.dgram import udp
from pysnmp.entity import engine, config
from pysnmp.entity.rfc3413 import cmdgen
from pysnmp.proto import rfc1902
from pysnmp import debug
import asyncio

# debug.setLogger(debug.Debug('all'))

# Create SNMP engine instance
snmpEngine = engine.SnmpEngine()

# SecurityName <-> CommunityName mapping
config.addV1System(snmpEngine, 'my-area', 'public')

# Specify security settings per SecurityName (SNMPv1 - 0, SNMPv2c - 1)
config.addTargetParams(snmpEngine, 'my-creds', 'my-area', 'noAuthNoPriv', 0)

# Setup transport endpoint and bind it with security settings yielding
# a target name
config.addTransport(
    snmpEngine,
    udp.domainName,
    udp.UdpTransport().openClientMode()
)
config.addTargetAddr(
    snmpEngine, 'my-router',
    udp.domainName, ('255.255.255.255', 161),
    'my-creds',
    # UDP broadcast needs to be explicitly enabled
    tagList='broadcast-agent-discovery'
)

# Specify broadcast addressing options
config.addSocketTransportOption(
    snmpEngine,
    udp.domainName,
    'broadcast-agent-discovery',
    # Enable UDP broadcasts at the socket level
    udp.enableBroadcast, 1
)

# Error/response receiver
async def cbFun(snmpEngine, sendRequestHandle, errorIndication,
         errorStatus, errorIndex, varBinds, cbCtx):
    if errorIndication:
        print(errorIndication)
        return

    # SNMPv1 response may contain noSuchName error *and* SNMPv2c exception,
    # so we ignore noSuchName error here
    if errorStatus and errorStatus != 2:
        print('%s at %s' % (errorStatus.prettyPrint(),
                            errorIndex and varBinds[int(errorIndex)-1][0] or '?'))
        return

    for varBind in varBinds:
        print(' = '.join([x.prettyPrint() for x in varBind]))

    # Continue enumeration for as long as non-empty varBinds are returned
    return True

# Prepare request to be sent yielding GetRequestPDU -> str
cmdgen.AsyncCommandGenerator().getCmd(
    snmpEngine,
    'my-router',
    ((1, 3, 6, 1, 2, 1, 1, 1, 0),),
    # User-space callback function and its context
    (cbFun, None)
)

# Run I/O dispatcher which would send pending queries and process
# responses
loop = asyncio.get_event_loop()
loop.run_until_complete(snmpEngine.transportDispatcher.runDispatcher())
```

TITLE: Sending SNMP TRAP Notifications
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to send SNMP TRAP notifications using PySNMP's notification originator API with asyncio support.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/examples/hlapi/v3arch/asyncio/index.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# This script is functionally identical to:
#
# $ snmptrap -v1 -c public demo.snmplabs.com 0 0.0.0.0 1 0 0 '' ''
#
# Note: it uses higher-level asyncio API

from pysnmp.hlapi.asyncio import *

async def run():
    snmpEngine = SnmpEngine()
    errorIndication, errorStatus, errorIndex, varBinds = await sendNotification(
        snmpEngine,
        CommunityData('public', mpModel=0),
        UdpTransportTarget(('demo.snmplabs.com', 162)),
        ContextData(),
        'trap',
        NotificationType(
            ObjectIdentity('1.3.6.1.6.3.1.1.5.2')
        )
    )

    if errorIndication:
        print(errorIndication)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    import asyncio
    asyncio.get_event_loop().run_until_complete(run())
```

builder = engine.get_mib_builder()
# Make ./mibs available to all OIDs that are created

TITLE: Implementing a Workaround for Negative Counter Values in Python
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet provides a hack to convert negated Counter values into their positive complimentaries. It modifies the clone method of Counter and Counter32 classes to handle negative values correctly.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/faq/ignored-snmp-packets.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
from pysnmp.proto import rfc1155, rfc1902, api
from pyasn1.codec.ber import encoder, decoder

# --- hack Counter type

def counterCloneHack(self, *args):
    if args and args[0] < 0:
        args = (0xffffffff+args[0]-1,) + args[1:]

    return self.__class__(*args)

rfc1155.Counter.clone = counterCloneHack
rfc1902.Counter32.clone = counterCloneHack
```

TITLE: Performing SNMPv2c GETBULK Operation with pysnmp and asyncio
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates how to perform an SNMPv2c GETBULK operation using pysnmp's high-level API with asyncio. It retrieves multiple OID values from an SNMP agent until the end of MIB is reached.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/examples/hlapi/v1arch/asyncio/manager/cmdgen/snmp-versions.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
# This script performs a series of SNMP GETBULK operations using the following options:
#
#   * SNMPv2c
#   * with community name 'public'
#   * over IPv4/UDP
#   * to an Agent at demo.snmplabs.com:161
#   * for some columns of the IF-MIB::ifTable table
#   * stop when response OIDs leave the scopes of the table
#
# This script performs similar to the following Net-SNMP command:
#
# $ snmpbulkwalk -v2c -c public -C n0 -Cr50 demo.snmplabs.com IF-MIB::ifTable

from pysnmp.hlapi.asyncio import *

async def run():
    snmpEngine = SnmpEngine()
    await bulkCmd(
        snmpEngine,
        CommunityData('public'),
        UdpTransportTarget(('demo.snmplabs.com', 161)),
        ContextData(),
        0, 50,
        ObjectType(ObjectIdentity('IF-MIB', 'ifDescr')),
        ObjectType(ObjectIdentity('IF-MIB', 'ifType')),
        ObjectType(ObjectIdentity('IF-MIB', 'ifMtu')),
        ObjectType(ObjectIdentity('IF-MIB', 'ifSpeed')),
        ObjectType(ObjectIdentity('IF-MIB', 'ifPhysAddress')),
        ObjectType(ObjectIdentity('IF-MIB', 'ifAdminStatus')),
        ObjectType(ObjectIdentity('IF-MIB', 'ifOperStatus')),
        lexicographicMode=False,
        lookupMib=True,
        ignoreNonIncreasingOid=True,
        
        # User-space callback function and its context
        cbFun=cbFun, cbCtx=snmpEngine
    )

async def cbFun(snmpEngine, sendRequestHandle, errorIndication,
                errorStatus, errorIndex, varBinds, cbCtx):
    if errorIndication:
        print(errorIndication)
        return
    elif errorStatus:
        print('%s at %s' % (errorStatus.prettyPrint(),
                            errorIndex and varBinds[int(errorIndex) - 1][0] or '?'))
        return
    else:
        for varBind in varBinds:
            print(' = '.join([x.prettyPrint() for x in varBind]))

    # Stop on EOM
    return True

if __name__ == '__main__':
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(run())
```

    ::= { system 3 }
```

TITLE: Capturing SNMP Traffic with tcpdump in Bash
DESCRIPTION: This snippet demonstrates the use of tcpdump to capture SNMP traffic, showing that responses are being sent by the device even when the PySNMP client reports a timeout.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/source/faq/ignored-snmp-packets.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: bash
CODE:
```
13:33:30.161843 IP 10.0.0.33.snmp > 10.0.0.1.51094: 
GetResponse(31)  interfaces.ifTable.ifEntry.ifInOctets.3=1532504859
13:33:30.161881 IP 10.0.0.33.snmp > 10.0.0.1.51094: 
GetResponse(31)  interfaces.ifTable.ifEntry.ifInOctets.3=1532504859
```

TITLE: Defining Source Address Entry Sequence and TAddress Object
DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines the SnmpSourceAddrEntry sequence structure and the snmpSourceAddrTAddress object which contains the transport address for source endpoints.
SOURCE: https://github.com/lextudio/pysnmp.git/blob/main/docs/mibs/PYSNMP-SOURCE-MIB.txt#2025-04-22_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: MIB
CODE:
```
SnmpSourceAddrEntry ::= SEQUENCE {
    snmpSourceAddrTAddress     TAddress
}

snmpSourceAddrTAddress OBJECT-TYPE
    SYNTAX      TAddress
    MAX-ACCESS  read-create
    STATUS      current
    DESCRIPTION
        "This object contains a transport address.  The format of
         this address depends on the value of the
         snmpSourceAddrTDomain object."
    ::= { snmpSourceAddrEntry 1 }
```

```
$ snmpget -v2c -c public 127.0.0.1 .1.3.6.1.4.1.14988.1.1.1.2.1.1.0.23.183.34.8.200.3
